commentBody: What?  No mention of Kathleen Ridder and Ridder Arena, the women's hockey facility at the University of Minnesota?!?! That building opened in 2002.
Maybe they should give money to support education (scholarships, books for the library) rather than silly sports.  College is supposed to be for education, not games.

I am personally offended by this deliberate discrimination against women and segregation of their athletic programs.
Since women are equal to men, they should be allowed to compete, without interference, in all sports programs, instead of being pushed into a program for inferior athletes.
It is time, and past time, to allow women to take their rightful place in the world of athletics, just as they are expected to be treated as equals in all other forms of human activities.
After all, we don't have "Women's physics" programs.
There are no "Women's seats" in congress.
Women's earnings are not subsidized to account for inferior performance in the business world.
So why athletics? Let's end this abomination, now!

I’d like to thank these Title IX pioneers for creating a world full of opportunities for my daughter.  I played two sports in college and I know what it meant to me.  These opportunities make a huge difference.  I know it’s “just sports,” but I certainly don’t want to undervalue things like team work, goal orientation, work ethic, determination, and confidence.  And let’s not leave out fun and joy.

I lived at home and attended Cornell University in the 50\'s.  A lonely slog.  If there had been a women\'s swim team I would surely have made it and had all EP\'s above mentioned benefits of being part of a goal oriented group.  My college life would have been much much better.\n     I saw a women\'s volleyball team in the airport recently on their way to a match...aglow with good health and "teamness" Hooray for Title IX.', 'createDate': '1575475245', 'updateDate': '1575867486', 'approveDate': '1575475246', 'recommendations': 6, 'replyCount': 0, 'replies': [], 'editorsSelection': False, 'parentID': 103959110, 'parentUserDisplayName': 'EP', 'depth': 2, 'commentType': 'userReply', 'trusted': 0, 'recommendedFlag': 0, 'permID': '103964049', 'isAnonymous': False}]

commentBody: Want to see what the power of female alum investment looks like on a college campus? Go check out Wellesley College—dedicated to women’s leadership and empowerment since 1870. Buildings are named after women, scholarships and fellowships are named after and largely funded by women, the impressive alum network is made up of women. It’s the #3 ranked liberal arts college in the country, and beyond sports, it’s all of and for women.

I am of two minds whenever I read about philanthropy: (1) kudos to the fortunate for sharing and giving (of course, the tax write-offs must be nice); (2) I have no objections to folks getting rich, but I do object - and most emphatically - about a criminally skewed/unfair tax system which allows individuals to accumulate great wealth, avoid taxes, or not pay their fair share at all.

The society in which they made their wealth was built by the contributions of working stiffs (someone has to pay for the hospitals, parks, roads, infrastructure, airports, garbage collection, schools, services, police, etc. that make a society livable and productive). Why is it that the burden falls so unfairly on those who cannot afford tax lawyers, tax havens, tax shelters . . .

What many of the commenters are missing is the fact that before Title IX those of us  who wanted to participate in sports because we enjoyed them couldn't. I was at the University of Michigan beginning in 1970. We had a gym designated as the women's gym but the showers were useless, the swimming pool had been condemned and there were very few opportunities for even intramural sports much less competitive sports. At public schools all students should have at least a reasonable opportunity to participate in sports. That's why I still support Title IX.
great story, rich people giving money to incredibly rich organizations and getting their names plastered on things.  It's payback time for title nine it seems, a good investment all around..

Semi-professional sports has no place in institutions of higher learning. It is one thing to follow the ancient Greek ideal of "healthy bodies and healthy minds", but that is quite different from the corruptive and corrosive influence  semi-professional sports has had on American institutions of higher learning.

The litany of systemic corruptive and corrosive events at US universities is almost endless, from systemic sexual abuse to fraud and bribery involving "sports" in order to get into a desired university.

commentBody:
And then there's the reality: In the photo we see a singular person in the grandstand watching the women's field hockey match. 

Is this an article about the right to participate in sports? Or the larger issue on income-generating sports at the university level and the inequality inherent when it comes to the tastes of the ticket buying public?

The WNBA is a professional basketball league. People don't buy tickets to see it. They don't want to watch it on broadcasts. Therefore it is not profitable. It is notoriously subsidized by the NBA. (US players make more money playing overseas than in the WNBA.)

If you have a product that does not sell, it is not an issue about equality. It is an issue about what the public wants to buy.

commentBody:
It is ok as long as today's women don't make the same mistake men made pre 1980, donate and discriminate against women.

In this case it would be against men.

What I mean is let anybody who wants to be an athlete an even break but don't identity obsess, social engineer, demand quotas, insist that women get 50%+ of everything whether they are qualified, interested or in extreme cases forced to take it.

commentBody: Now if we can only get women to pay to attend women’s college sporting events. Please don’t cite me UConn women’s basketball. Instead cite to me a women’s volleyball program that generates more revenue than its expenses.

[{'commentID': 103953564, 'status': 'approved', 'commentSequence': 103953564, 'userID': 48129895, 'userDisplayName': 'rella', 'userLocation': 'VA', 'userTitle': 'NULL', 'userURL': 'NULL', 'picURL': None, 'commentTitle': '<br\//>', 'commentBody': "@Shamrock  Are you assuming that only women would be interested in attending women's college sporting events?  I've seen my share of college women's volleyball on TV, and my impression is that at the schools with the biggest and most committed fan bases (Nebraska, Penn State, etc.), more than half of the people in the stands are men.  If you want to generate more revenue, you should market to whoever is interested, as opposed to your preconceptions as to who would be interested.", 'createDate': '1575413439', 'updateDate': '1575554092', 'approveDate': '1575413440', 'recommendations': 8, 'replyCount': 0, 'replies': [], 'editorsSelection': False, 'parentID': 103947137, 'parentUserDisplayName': 'Shamrock', 'depth': 2, 'commentType': 'userReply', 'trusted': 0, 'recommendedFlag': 0, 'permID': '103953564', 'isAnonymous': False}, {'commentID': 103952693, 'status': 'approved', 'commentSequence': 103952693, 'userID': 58543247, 'userDisplayName': 'Economist', 'userLocation': 'Virginia', 'userTitle': 'NULL', 'userURL': 'NULL', 'picURL': None, 'commentTitle': '<br\//>', 'commentBody': "@Shamrock How many people do you think are paying to attend Yale lacrosse games (men's or women's)?  How many are paying to attend swim meets? Or tennis matches? Or soccer games, etc.? 

 The fact is that we have evolved to a system where there are basically two types of sports in college these days -- those meant to produce a *sports entertainment*  product such as FBS football and men's D1 basketball.  For some schools these sports are net revenue generators, but according to NCAA data, at  most schools they require large subsidies from the university's budget. 

The other type of sports are those that have little or no value as a *sports entertainment* product but, which are primarily still in place to benefit the student athlete, and increasingly in DII and DIII to help schools with enrollment management (e.g., Adrian College in Michigan). In this latter category of college sports, why shouldn't the women's tennis team/soccer team/lacrosse team/swim team/etc.  have facilities as nice as the men's teams?

BTW:  I am a former varsity athlete.", 'createDate': '1575410595', 'updateDate': '1575477955', 'approveDate': '1575436023', 'recommendations': 5, 'replyCount': 0, 'replies': [], 'editorsSelection': False, 'parentID': 103947137, 'parentUserDisplayName': 'Shamrock', 'depth': 2, 'commentType': 'userReply', 'trusted': 0, 'recommendedFlag': 0, 'permID': '103952693', 'isAnonymous': False}, {'commentID': 103956470, 'status': 'approved', 'commentSequence': 103956470, 'userID': 68662423, 'userDisplayName': 'Letitia Jeavons', 'userLocation': 'Pennsylvania', 'userTitle': 'NULL', 'userURL': 'NULL', 'picURL': None, 'commentTitle': '<br\//>', 'commentBody': "@Shamrock straight women play sports and even LGBT athletes have brothers. commentBody: The legacy of Title IX should be a source of pride for all Americans. I only wish its success in athletics was spread to women's early family and childbearing years.
Great. More money in college athletics. Nothing could go wrong. There will never be a scandal about women’s rowing.

commentBody:
We need to get this crazy idea out of our collective brains that collegiate sports have any value at non-profit education institution whose one and only purpose is supposedly the advancement of scholarly pursuits. 

Just survey the rest of the western world and realize what value sports have at the collegiate level. Zero!

Let's hope all the female athletes and women who have worked so hard to promote women in sports don't see all their efforts go up in the smoke of the new normal of transwomen--males--invading women's sports.

Wonderful to read, especially as Alumni Development is never easy, even for the elite schools. The large donors are increasingly a rare breed, and thankfully, a greater number of women now have the means and the willingness to be leadership donors. One only hopes such Giving becomes a trend throughout all the universities of this nation, in some way.

commentBody:
I know the tone of this article is hopeful and tangentially about equality, but we're going in the wrong direction.

Why should anyone support more money going into the college athletics system?

Ole Miss just fired their football coach and will incur between $12M and $17M in guaranteed payments.  This is insane.

We should be moving towards having all college sports resemble something closer to high school or intramural sports, not towards pro-style spending.

[{'commentID': 103950729, 'status': 'approved', 'commentSequence': 103950729, 'userID': 79034748, 'userDisplayName': 'Kohl', 'userLocation': 'Ohio', 'userTitle': 'NULL', 'userURL': 'NULL', 'picURL': None, 'commentTitle': '<br\//>', 'commentBody': '@MTS I get it, you think college athletics are a waste of money. I totally understand that opinion. However, you should do some research to further understand the value that college athletics provide. Every time a college plays a football game on TV, that school receives 4 hours of publicity on TV for free. The TV network will actually pay the school for its game to be on their network. How much do you think 480 30-second spots would cost for a tv watched by millions?  This is just one example, there are many more ways in which athletics provide a net benefit to schools.', 'createDate': '1575405079', 'updateDate': '1575413016', 'approveDate': '1575405080', 'recommendations': 1, 'replyCount': 0, 'replies': [], 'editorsSelection': False, 'parentID': 103949125, 'parentUserDisplayName': 'MTS', 'depth': 2, 'commentType': 'userReply', 'trusted': 0, 'recommendedFlag': 0, 'permID': '103950729', 'isAnonymous': False}, {'commentID': 103954677, 'status': 'approved', 'commentSequence': 103954677, 'userID': 12981476, 'userDisplayName': 'MTS', 'userLocation': 'Kendall Park, NJ', 'userTitle': 'NULL', 'userURL': 'NULL', 'picURL': None, 'commentTitle': '<br\//>', 'commentBody': '@Kohl 
Sure Ohio got a bunch of free advertising this weekend.  For every Ohio or Alabama or Clemson, there are 50 football programs losing millions of dollars because they all think they can hit the jackpot.  And the ads for everything but football and basketball are de minimis.

Also - aren't there better ways to draw kids to your school - like improving the school?  I've never seen a TV ad for Harvard, Yale, Princeton . . . yet they get plenty of applicants.  And I can't imagine any future Rhodes Scholars who watched a football, basketball or soccer game and thought - "I should go to that school that just scored".', 'createDate': '1575417730', 'updateDate': '1575478911', 'approveDate': '1575417731', 'recommendations': 3, 'replyCount': 0, 'replies': [], 'editorsSelection': False, 'parentID': 103950729, 'parentUserDisplayName': 'MTS', 'depth': 2, 'commentType': 'userReply', 'trusted': 0, 'recommendedFlag': 0, 'permID': '103954677', 'isAnonymous': False}, {'commentID': 103952478, 'status': 'approved', 'commentSequence': 103952478, 'userID': 81724884, 'userDisplayName': 'Riley2', 'userLocation': 'Norcal', 'userTitle': 'NULL', 'userURL': 'NULL', 'picURL': None, 'commentTitle': '<br\//>', 'commentBody': '@Kohl

I’ve done the research, and I’m convinced elite sports and institutions of higher learning shouldn’t mix. Very few sports programs run in the black financially, despite what’s commonly believed. They’re a drain on resources. What’s more, the system is rife with corruption, from lowering athletes’ academic standards for admission, to grossly watering down their scholastic experience once enrolled, to discarding them if injured - often with no degree. And along with all that, a nasty overtone of racism and exploitation of low income kids. Plus, and most importantly, it adds up to a huge distraction from what ought to be the missions  of a university: education and research.', 'createDate': '1575409935', 'updateDate': '1575465216', 'approveDate': '1575436023', 'recommendations': 3, 'replyCount': 0, 'replies': [], 'editorsSelection': False, 'parentID': 103949125, 'parentUserDisplayName': 'MTS', 'depth': 2, 'commentType': 'userReply', 'trusted': 0, 'recommendedFlag': 0, 'permID': '103952478', 'isAnonymous': False}]

commentBody:
This plays a huge role in equality for women’s sports, both short and long term. Having people simply *care* is an essential step for garnering respect from both men and women and, in turn, attracting fans and more funding. 

Women recognizing they want cool things too isn’t a bad thing. And raising the bar on a collegiate level will assist or even force woman’s professional leagues to act accordingly. 

Mostly excited to read this because sometimes I feel like the only woman who loves her sport to death and wants to see its athletes and programs receive due respect. I’m not alone!

commentBody: This is fantastic.  It’s great to see student athletes going on to succeed in something other than professional sports and giving back.  To the naysayers, are people not free to donate money in the manner they choose? and endowing scholarships is never a bad thing.
Wouldn't these multimillion dollar donations be better spent on actually improving access to education for thousands of underprivileged women?

commentBody:
Sad. Huge donations to Yale, Virginia, Indiana, Notre Dame, William & Mary. All with massive endowments already, well over $1 billion each with the exception of W&M at $950 MM. 

The rich do get richer, all while local community colleges can only afford to hire adjuncts.
